title: How to Make Wontons

steps.headline: Combine water, flour and salt in a bowl.
steps.description: In a large bowl, combine ⁄3  c (79 mL) of water with 2 cups (256 g) of all-purpose flour and ½ a teaspoon (2.8 g) of salt. Mix them thoroughly until they form a smooth ball of dough. As you stir, pull stuck flour off the bowl to incorporate it in the dough. If the dough becomes dry, mix in about 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of water at a time until it reaches a solid consistency. You can also mix in an egg for additional consistency. Another option is to buy premade wonton wrappers. Supermarkets may sell them. You can fill them and cook them right away.

steps.headline: Knead the dough for 5 minutes on a floured surface.
steps.description: You can use any flat surface you have available, including a clean countertop or large cutting board. Dust the surface with flour before dumping the dough onto it. To knead the dough, use the heel of your hand to push it forward, then roll it back towards you. Continue doing this until the dough is firm but smooth. Knead the dough at a steady rhythm. It does get exhausting, so make sure you’re prepared. Have someone else on hand to step in if you think you will need the help. The dough will look smooth and hold its shape when it is ready. If it still looks lumpy, add more flour to your work surface and continue kneading.

steps.headline: Cover the dough with a damp cloth for 1 hour.
steps.description: Leave the dough out on the countertop or place it in a large, clean bowl. After dampening a clean cloth, squeeze excess moisture out of it before draping it over the dough. The cloth prevents the dough from drying out as it rests. If you don’t have a towel available, cover the dough with plastic wrap. You can also try keeping it in a large pot covered by a lid. You can also divide the dough in half before covering each ball with a separate cloth. Let the dough balls rest for at least 10 minutes.

steps.headline: Divide the dough in half and roll it into squares.
steps.description: After splitting the dough, use a rolling pin to flatten each ball individually. Aim to make each square about 15 in × 9 in (38 cm × 23 cm) in size. You can dust your work surface with cornstarch to prevent the dough from sticking. You can also divide the dough into 4 balls, then roll them into 10 ⁄2 in × 10 ⁄2 in (27 cm × 27 cm) squares. It doesn’t make much difference, but the smaller dough balls may be easier to handle.

steps.headline: Cut the dough into 3 ⁄2 in × 3 ⁄2 in (8.9 cm × 8.9 cm) squares.
steps.description: A dough knife or bench scraper is the best tool for the job, but you can use any large, sharp knife. Cutting the dough will give you individual wonton wrappers ready to be filled and cooked. Try to keep the wrappers an even size so they cook at the same rate when you make the wontons. If you don’t have time to make your own dough, you can always try buying premade wrappers at the supermarket.

steps.headline: Mix a filling for the wontons out of vegetables and other ingredients.
steps.description: There are many filling variations in the world, so get creative! Combine a few of your favorite ingredients to make your wontons unique. Cream cheese is a popular filling type. You can also try incorporating ground pork or shrimp. For a simple cream cheese filling, mix together cream cheese, hot sauce, and green onions. Make a pork filling by combining ground pork, garlic, ginger, soy sauce, sesame oil, and vegetables like carrots and celery.

steps.headline: Place a scoop of filling in the center of a wonton wrapper.
steps.description: Work on 1 wonton at a time, wrapping and sealing it before moving on to the next one. Scoop about 1 teaspoon (4.2 g) of filling onto the wrapper. Flatten the filling out as much as you can, but keep it it in the center of the wonton so it doesn’t leak out when you fold the wrapper. Spooning generous amounts of filling is tempting, but err on the side of caution to avoid having the wontons fall apart on you as they cook. Wonton dough is pretty delicate. If you try to do too much at once, the wrappers can dry out. Leaving scoops of moist filling on the wrappers also causes problems since the wrappers may absorb moisture and fall apart. Start small and avoid rushing.

steps.headline: Beat an egg and use it to coat the edges of the wonton.
steps.description: The egg wash is the glue that will hold your wontons together. Make sure the wrapper edges are accessible and free of filling. Then, dip your finger into the egg and drag it along the edges to create a “glue” border. Turn the egg into an egg wash by mixing it with ⁄2  c (120 mL) of water. If you plan on making a large batch of wontons, this gives you more egg “glue” to work with. You can also forgo the egg by spreading water around the edges of the wrappers. An egg wash provides more sticking power, but many times water is enough to hold the wontons together.

steps.headline: Wrap the wonton by folding its edges together.
steps.description: To fold the wonton, pick up 2 opposite corners of the wrapper. Pinch them together above the center of the wonton and push them down to drive out air caught inside the wrapper. Repeat this with the remaining 2 corners to create a little wonton package you can drop into a cooking liquid. There are many ways to fold a wonton. As long as you get the wontons to hold together and cook through, any folding method is valid.

steps.headline: Place the wonton under plastic wrap before wrapping more.
steps.description: Your hard work can fall apart if you don’t store it correctly. Set out a baking sheet and place each wonton on it. Leave space between each wonton and avoid stacking them. Keep the wontons covered with plastic wrap at all times to prevent them from drying out. You can also cover the wontons with a light, dry towel. Uncooked wontons can easily be frozen this way. Put parchment paper on the baking tray so the wontons don’t stick. Then, place the covered tray in the freezer for about an hour. Once the wontons have frozen through, move them to resealable containers in the freezer. They will lat from 4 to 6 months.

steps.headline: Heat about 3 in (7.6 cm) of vegetable oil to 375 °F (191 °C).
steps.description: Fill a pot or wok with the oil. It is important to add enough oil for the wontons to float in. Also, check the oil with a kitchen thermometer to ensure the wonton wrappers will turn crispy and brown when you cook them. Be careful with hot oil. If the oil gets too hot, it will burn the wontons. Wontons can also be cooked by boiling them. Boil about 4  c (950 mL) of water, then add the wontons. You can also use broth to make wonton soup.

steps.headline: Cook a small batch of wontons for about 1 minute.
steps.description: Drop 4 to 6 wontons into the oil. Let them sit undisturbed in the oil until the bottom half begins to brown. If the wontons aren’t submerged in the oil, you’re cooking too many at once. Cook only a few at a time so they soak and fry evenly.

steps.headline: Flip the wontons over and brown them for another minute.
steps.description: Use a pair of tongs to turn the wontons over in the oil. After another minute of frying, they should all be an even, crisp shade of brown. If they look a little pale or soft, continue frying them for a few more minutes. If the oil is deep enough, such as when using a deep fryer, the wontons will float to the surface. This can take as long as 4 minutes depending on how hot the oil is.

steps.headline: Drain the wontons on a paper towel for about 10 minutes.
steps.description: Take the wontons out of the oil with a slotted spoon or tongs. Spread paper towels out on a flat surface and leave the wontons there to allow the filling time to cool. As the wontons cool, the paper towels will absorb excess oil. You can start frying another batch as you wait.

steps.headline: Store the wontons in the refrigerator for up to 4 days.
steps.description: Move the wontons to plastic bags or containers within 2 hours of cooking them. Make sure the containers are sealed before storing them. When the wontons start to soften, smell rancid, or turn moldy, throw them away. You can also put the wontons in sealed containers in the freezer. They will last up to 6 months. Wonton soup will last about the same length of time as regular wontons. However, keep in mind that the wontons tend to get soggy when stored in the soup. Try storing them separately from the broth. The best way to freeze wontons is before they are cooked. When you’re ready to use them, pull them out of the freezer and cook as many as you need.

steps.headline: Boil half a pot of water on the stove.
steps.description: Fill a wok or a pot about halfway full and bring it to a bubble. Once it boils, reduce the heat to a simmer.

steps.headline: Cook the wontons for about 3 minutes or until they float.
steps.description: Drop the wontons into the pot, making sure they are submerged. Add only a few at a time so they form a single layer at the bottom of the pot. When the wontons finish cooking, they rise to the water’s surface. Depending on the size of your pot, you will need to add the wontons in batches. Usually, you can fit about 5 or 6 in a pot at a time.

steps.headline: Remove the wontons with a slotted spoon.
steps.description: Fish the wontons out of the pot, moving them to serving plates. Add any garnishes, such as chives, before serving them. Avoid leaving the wontons in the water or else they will fall apart.

text: Making Wonton Wrappers from Dough Combine water, flour and salt in a bowl. In a large bowl, combine ⁄3  c (79 mL) of water with 2 cups (256 g) of all-purpose flour and ½ a teaspoon (2.8 g) of salt. Mix them thoroughly until they form a smooth ball of dough. As you stir, pull stuck flour off the bowl to incorporate it in the dough. If the dough becomes dry, mix in about 1 teaspoon (4.9 mL) of water at a time until it reaches a solid consistency. You can also mix in an egg for additional consistency. Another option is to buy premade wonton wrappers. Supermarkets may sell them. You can fill them and cook them right away. Knead the dough for 5 minutes on a floured surface. You can use any flat surface you have available, including a clean countertop or large cutting board. Dust the surface with flour before dumping the dough onto it. To knead the dough, use the heel of your hand to push it forward, then roll it back towards you. Continue doing this until the dough is firm but smooth. Knead the dough at a steady rhythm. It does get exhausting, so make sure you’re prepared. Have someone else on hand to step in if you think you will need the help. The dough will look smooth and hold its shape when it is ready. If it still looks lumpy, add more flour to your work surface and continue kneading. Cover the dough with a damp cloth for 1 hour. Leave the dough out on the countertop or place it in a large, clean bowl. After dampening a clean cloth, squeeze excess moisture out of it before draping it over the dough. The cloth prevents the dough from drying out as it rests. If you don’t have a towel available, cover the dough with plastic wrap. You can also try keeping it in a large pot covered by a lid. You can also divide the dough in half before covering each ball with a separate cloth. Let the dough balls rest for at least 10 minutes. Divide the dough in half and roll it into squares. After splitting the dough, use a rolling pin to flatten each ball individually. Aim to make each square about 15 in × 9 in (38 cm × 23 cm) in size. You can dust your work surface with cornstarch to prevent the dough from sticking. You can also divide the dough into 4 balls, then roll them into 10 ⁄2 in × 10 ⁄2 in (27 cm × 27 cm) squares. It doesn’t make much difference, but the smaller dough balls may be easier to handle. Cut the dough into 3 ⁄2 in × 3 ⁄2 in (8.9 cm × 8.9 cm) squares. A dough knife or bench scraper is the best tool for the job, but you can use any large, sharp knife. Cutting the dough will give you individual wonton wrappers ready to be filled and cooked. Try to keep the wrappers an even size so they cook at the same rate when you make the wontons. If you don’t have time to make your own dough, you can always try buying premade wrappers at the supermarket. Filling and Folding Wonton Wrappers Mix a filling for the wontons out of vegetables and other ingredients. There are many filling variations in the world, so get creative! Combine a few of your favorite ingredients to make your wontons unique. Cream cheese is a popular filling type. You can also try incorporating ground pork or shrimp. For a simple cream cheese filling, mix together cream cheese, hot sauce, and green onions. Make a pork filling by combining ground pork, garlic, ginger, soy sauce, sesame oil, and vegetables like carrots and celery. Place a scoop of filling in the center of a wonton wrapper. Work on 1 wonton at a time, wrapping and sealing it before moving on to the next one. Scoop about 1 teaspoon (4.2 g) of filling onto the wrapper. Flatten the filling out as much as you can, but keep it it in the center of the wonton so it doesn’t leak out when you fold the wrapper. Spooning generous amounts of filling is tempting, but err on the side of caution to avoid having the wontons fall apart on you as they cook. Wonton dough is pretty delicate. If you try to do too much at once, the wrappers can dry out. Leaving scoops of moist filling on the wrappers also causes problems since the wrappers may absorb moisture and fall apart. Start small and avoid rushing. Beat an egg and use it to coat the edges of the wonton. The egg wash is the glue that will hold your wontons together. Make sure the wrapper edges are accessible and free of filling. Then, dip your finger into the egg and drag it along the edges to create a “glue” border. Turn the egg into an egg wash by mixing it with ⁄2  c (120 mL) of water. If you plan on making a large batch of wontons, this gives you more egg “glue” to work with. You can also forgo the egg by spreading water around the edges of the wrappers. An egg wash provides more sticking power, but many times water is enough to hold the wontons together. Wrap the wonton by folding its edges together. To fold the wonton, pick up 2 opposite corners of the wrapper. Pinch them together above the center of the wonton and push them down to drive out air caught inside the wrapper. Repeat this with the remaining 2 corners to create a little wonton package you can drop into a cooking liquid. There are many ways to fold a wonton. As long as you get the wontons to hold together and cook through, any folding method is valid. Place the wonton under plastic wrap before wrapping more. Your hard work can fall apart if you don’t store it correctly. Set out a baking sheet and place each wonton on it. Leave space between each wonton and avoid stacking them. Keep the wontons covered with plastic wrap at all times to prevent them from drying out. You can also cover the wontons with a light, dry towel. Uncooked wontons can easily be frozen this way. Put parchment paper on the baking tray so the wontons don’t stick. Then, place the covered tray in the freezer for about an hour. Once the wontons have frozen through, move them to resealable containers in the freezer. They will lat from 4 to 6 months. Frying Wontons Heat about 3 in (7.6 cm) of vegetable oil to 375 °F (191 °C). Fill a pot or wok with the oil. It is important to add enough oil for the wontons to float in. Also, check the oil with a kitchen thermometer to ensure the wonton wrappers will turn crispy and brown when you cook them. Be careful with hot oil. If the oil gets too hot, it will burn the wontons. Wontons can also be cooked by boiling them. Boil about 4  c (950 mL) of water, then add the wontons. You can also use broth to make wonton soup. Cook a small batch of wontons for about 1 minute. Drop 4 to 6 wontons into the oil. Let them sit undisturbed in the oil until the bottom half begins to brown. If the wontons aren’t submerged in the oil, you’re cooking too many at once. Cook only a few at a time so they soak and fry evenly. Flip the wontons over and brown them for another minute. Use a pair of tongs to turn the wontons over in the oil. After another minute of frying, they should all be an even, crisp shade of brown. If they look a little pale or soft, continue frying them for a few more minutes. If the oil is deep enough, such as when using a deep fryer, the wontons will float to the surface. This can take as long as 4 minutes depending on how hot the oil is. Drain the wontons on a paper towel for about 10 minutes. Take the wontons out of the oil with a slotted spoon or tongs. Spread paper towels out on a flat surface and leave the wontons there to allow the filling time to cool. As the wontons cool, the paper towels will absorb excess oil. You can start frying another batch as you wait. Store the wontons in the refrigerator for up to 4 days. Move the wontons to plastic bags or containers within 2 hours of cooking them. Make sure the containers are sealed before storing them. When the wontons start to soften, smell rancid, or turn moldy, throw them away. You can also put the wontons in sealed containers in the freezer. They will last up to 6 months. Wonton soup will last about the same length of time as regular wontons. However, keep in mind that the wontons tend to get soggy when stored in the soup. Try storing them separately from the broth. The best way to freeze wontons is before they are cooked. When you’re ready to use them, pull them out of the freezer and cook as many as you need. Boiling Wontons Boil half a pot of water on the stove. Fill a wok or a pot about halfway full and bring it to a bubble. Once it boils, reduce the heat to a simmer. Cook the wontons for about 3 minutes or until they float. Drop the wontons into the pot, making sure they are submerged. Add only a few at a time so they form a single layer at the bottom of the pot. When the wontons finish cooking, they rise to the water’s surface. Depending on the size of your pot, you will need to add the wontons in batches. Usually, you can fit about 5 or 6 in a pot at a time. Remove the wontons with a slotted spoon. Fish the wontons out of the pot, moving them to serving plates. Add any garnishes, such as chives, before serving them. Avoid leaving the wontons in the water or else they will fall apart.
